body: I think this will work out, so +1
Thanks! :+1:

Thanks for the pull request. :)

Sorry for taking so long to merge. :(

The fix will be in the next release (2.4.6).

Hi John,

thanks for taking this on. You write

> I also added another commit to ensure the factory returned by the engine is the same factory that created it. I couldn't see a reason why each engine instance should return a new factory.

but the pull request is just a single commit?
Hi Pascal, I must have inadvertently squashed the commit I referred to.  I've broken it out again.  Thanks for pointing that out.
+1 nice finds, I thought I already removed all of these checks

There is a thread on the mlvm-dev list (http://mail.openjdk.java.net/pipermail/mlvm-dev/2016-January/006563.html) about the `ClassValue` bug that is related to this and some good information was provided by Peter.  I'm hoping to get some time to take a closer look and see if it might be possible to revert back to using `ClassValue` as the default if available.  But even with CV without these changes we'd still have a leak with jdk6.

It would be nice if we could merge PR #220 since these changes rely on those being in place.
This changes 454 files....

I do agree with the final changes, they are good. But assuming metaClass is not volatile, where would you expect a problem? Having a partially initialized meta class object being published must not be a problem, or half of Groovy has a big problem. Every meta class is itself responsible for its part being properly visible. So -1 on the volatile

Yes, a few files were affected. :smile: 

That is why I left as 2 commits in case such a big change isn't accepted at this time but in case we want to add just the `.gitattributes` file to make sure line endings are ok going forward.  This big of a change should probably have everyone's agreement and be coordinated since it wouldn't be fun to handle merge conflicts.  If you run a `git diff -w master..<this branch>` only the new file should show.  All tests passed locally, waiting for the PR hook to be fixed to see if CI server passes.

Thanks for the feedback I appreciate it.  In looking at the [MetaClassImpl](https://github.com/apache/groovy/blob/2046dd76bdbb7398d425e83a7d9b39a0a8707c9a/src/main/groovy/lang/MetaClassImpl.java#L148-L160) I just noticed a few non-final instance variables.  But most aren't really part of the initialization that I can tell other than the `FastArray constructors` and `MetaClassRegistry registry` and both look like candidates to be final.

Guess I was just being overly cautious since lazy initialization can be tricky.  I'll update the PR and remove the `volatile`.
PR updated to remove final.  Included a few minor changes to the subclasses.
I doubt this is really what was intended: -1
agreed -1
merge  request ?

Below are the affected file counts by directory, the bulk of EOL changes being in `src/test`.

 52 - src/main/groovy
 70 - src/main/org/codehaus/groovy
291 - src/test
 26 - src/examples
  5 - subprojects/groovy-jmx

Misc (9):

config/bnd/groovy-all.bnd
config/bnd/groovy.bnd
config/checkstyle/codeHeader.txt
gradlew.bat
src/main/META-INF/groovy-release-info.properties
src/main/META-INF/services/org.codehaus.groovy.source.Extensions
src/main/META-INF/services/org.codehaus.groovy.transform.ASTTransformation
src/main/overview.html
src/main/overviewj.html

No need for a big change all at once, probably be best to slowly phase it in.  Maybe starting with `src/examples` and `groovy-jmx` since those probably wouldn't create merge conflicts with open PR's or in-progress work.

Of course it's perfectly valid to not do anything and leave EOL's as is.
Would .attributes just be for new files, or will it modify the line endings as soon as there is a change to a file?
No negative feedback, plenty of tests, build passes. I guess this is good to merge?
@melix @blackdrag could you take a look at this if you haven't already? @PascalSchumacher I also want to add a test for the case of multiple bridge methods before merging.

Both.  It will modify the line endings if you change a file.  For example, if you make a one line change to `src/main/org/codehaus/groovy/runtime/ConversionHandler.java` it will change all line endings when you commit that change.  So normal diff's in git or github will show the whole file as changed unless you add `-w` and `&w=1` respectively.  The line endings of the working copy wont be changed so they'll be warnings on each future commit unless the working copy is reset.  But after the first commit to normalize the line endings future changes should only show what changed (regardless of line endings in the working copy).

That means we will still get problems with finding out about the history of a specific line. Furthermore I am wondering about files like gradlew.bat. This is a windows file and bat expects windows line endings afaik. So could this change cause problems here?
I would have liked Cedric to comment here, but if he has no time atm, then I suggest to just merge it. He can still complain later ;) The commit itself looks good to me

> That means we will still get problems with finding out about the history of a specific line. 

If we did the conversion there would be one more commit in the history for a line in the files affected.  However, a line is still a line so you should be able to still see the commits of particular line.

> Furthermore I am wondering about files like gradlew.bat. This is a windows file and bat expects windows line endings afaik. So could this change cause problems here?

The `.gitattributes` let you specify an override for certain files so they can retain CRLF endings.  I have `.bat` files set like that in this change.

```
# Windows files
*.bat           text eol=crlf 
```

So that's why `src/bin/*.bat` files were not affected.  The `gradlew.bat` was affected because it actually had Linux line endings so they were converted to Windows.
I also tested these changes against the test script provided in GROOVY-7621 and do not get OOME and all iterations complete.

Wow, thanks so much John!
This is the kind of thing that's going to really make groovy "the Best" language!

@blackdrag just curious if you think these changes look ok?

While they don't directly address some of the issues, I did notice in testing GROOVY-7621 these changes consistently enabled it to go more iterations before an OOME.
Merged, thanks for reviewing.
just noticed, that this is for the 2.3.x branch... the fix should of course into master and all maintained versions
Thanks! :+1:
I guess this should be closed? (It broke some tests on the team city as far as I remember.)
@blackdrag @melxi @shils Any hints for @antoaravinth or should we close this pull request?
Paul: What do think, is this worth keeping open, or better of closed (to reduce the number of open pull requests)?
Thanks!
@shils Looks good as far as I can tell. Thanks for all your excellent work on groovy. :+1: Can you rebase this?
Thanks!
I merged the pull request. Of course you are still welcome to extend it to other constants. :)
@PascalSchumacher Thanks. I've been getting pulled in a lot of directions for the past two months. I'll try to circle back for the other ones noted above!
eval exec strikes me as a code smell. There must be a better way of dealing with the quoting problem here.

I agree catalina.sh uses `eval exec "\"$X\""`
Not sure where I got the extra \$ of `eval exec "\"\$X\"`.

A little testing with local shellscripts seems to indicate it doesn't matter (which means I am probably overlooking something).

```
#!/bin/bash
CMD="./testrun.sh"
OPTS="'foo bar' \"bar baz\" \"\\\"quoted argument\\\"\""
ARG="x y"
(
  echo test1
  eval exec "\"\$CMD\"" "\"\$ARG\"" $OPTS
)
echo 
(
  echo test2
  eval exec "\"$CMD\"" "\"$ARG\"" $OPTS
)
```

with my testrun.sh being a simple loop that prints out the number of arguments and then one argument per line

```
#!/bin/bash
echo '$#='"$#"
i=0
for VAR in "$@"
do
    echo "$i:$VAR"
    i=$((i + 1))
done
```

I can not find a scenario that causes them to have different outputs.
For sake of consistency with catalina, I will probalby remove the extra \$ sequences.
Merged: c1516a8180a06c88be2fab18bea4d06062591790 Thanks!

K, stand corrected. When I use an `ARG="x' \" y"`, the second test `eval exec "\"$ARG\""` breaks with a parser error.

I think the escape of the $ in "\"\$X\"" is needed so that the value from X is not expanded until after the last pass of interpolation. i.e. the eval pass instead of being substituted in during the outer bash execution and then getting its value eval'd.

BTW tomcat will fail if any of those $X variables contain a double-quote character e.g.

```
~/Developer/opt/tomcat"dir$ ./bin/catalina.sh run
Using CATALINA_BASE:   /XXX/Developer/opt/tomcat"dir
Using CATALINA_HOME:   /XXX/Developer/opt/tomcat"dir
Using CATALINA_TMPDIR: /XXX/Developer/opt/tomcat"dir/temp
Using JRE_HOME:        /usr/lib/jvm/java-7-oracle
Using CLASSPATH:           /XXX/Developer/opt/tomcat"dir/bin/bootstrap.jar:/XXX/Developer/opt/tomcat"dir/bin/tomcat-juli.jar
./bin/catalina.sh: 1: eval: Syntax error: Unterminated quoted string
```

BTW after applying my fix to catalina.sh, tomcat Boostrap.java forbids double-quotes in classpath elements arbitrarily(?). But I can pass a CATALINA_TMPDIR that uses a double-quote literal char

```
$ CATALINA_TMPDIR=/tmp/catalina\"dir ./bin/catalina.sh run 
Using CATALINA_BASE:   /home/XXX/Developer/projects/apache/tomcat80/output/build
Using CATALINA_HOME:   /home/XXX/Developer/projects/apache/tomcat80/output/build
Using CATALINA_TMPDIR: /tmp/catalina"dir
Using JRE_HOME:        /usr/lib/jvm/java-7-oracle
Using CLASSPATH:           /home/XXX/Developer/projects/apache/tomcat80/output/build/bin/bootstrap.jar:/home/XXX/Developer/projects/apache/tomcat80/output/build/bin/tomcat-juli.jar
./bin/catalina.sh: 1: eval: Syntax error: Unterminated quoted string
```

vs a functional tomcat

```
$ CATALINA_TMPDIR=/tmp/catalina\"dir ./bin/catalina.sh run 
Using CATALINA_BASE:   /home/XXX/Developer/projects/apache/tomcat80/output/build
Using CATALINA_HOME:   /home/XXX/Developer/projects/apache/tomcat80/output/build
Using CATALINA_TMPDIR: /tmp/catalina"dir
Using JRE_HOME:        /usr/lib/jvm/java-7-oracle
Using CLASSPATH:       /home/XXX/Developer/projects/apache/tomcat80/output/build/bin/bootstrap.jar:/home/XXX/Developer/projects/apache/tomcat80/output/build/bin/tomcat-juli.jar
15-Jan-2016 16:11:11.726 INFO [main] org.apache.catalina.startup.VersionLoggerListener.log     Server version:    Apache Tomcat/8.0.31-dev
15-Jan-2016 16:11:11.727 INFO [main] org.apache.catalina.startup.VersionLoggerListener.log Server built:          Jan 15 2016 21:07:24 UTC
```
You're right, sorry about that, I wasn't testing with `eval` so that was my mistake.

@russel I agree it is messy looking and smells bad. Unfortunately when I last looked into this and compared with tomcat and ant, it seems like a sort of necessary evil.
Ant's structure looks slightly better where they assign the string to a var then eval that var. But they actually have the same flaw if any of the quoted items contain double-quote (JAVACMD, LOCALCLASSPATH, ANT_HOME etc)

```
ant_exec_command="exec \"$JAVACMD\" $ANT_OPTS ...."
eval $ant_exec_command
```

Again escaping the $ to defer the expansion until eval resolves that problem. The ant pattern seems more readable.
Rebased. Thanks @PascalSchumacher , the feeling is mutual.
The issue only seems to occur when a shift operator is used within a closure, so I'd suggest looking at how the static compiler handles `register >>> 56` when it's located outside of a closure.
This shouldn't be merged until a decision has been made and carried out for backporting GROOVY-7705.
Thanks! :+1:

Is it common to order by first name in the english speaking parts of the world?

@PascalSchumacher 
Not sure about that. If we are taking cultural differences into account then a simpler thing to do would be to just remove the part about sorting. :smile:
Thanks! :+1:

So basically you find, you need to generate those bridge methods, and leave it to a later visitor to actually produce that code... The alternative would be to write a visitor that can adds this information and is run from StaticCompilationVisitor, to let the actual adding of those methods be done by the StaticCompilationVisitor later on. But actually the list of inner classes in the classnode is supposed to contain all inner classes at this stage, so I am not sure you even need a full blown visitor for this. What do you think
Thanks! :+1:
Thanks for the pull request. I decided to keep the current sorting by surname.

If I understand correctly, your suggestion is to have the StaticCompilationVisitor for an inner class or method add bridge methods to its outer class? The issue there is that there may be multiple statically compiled inner classes/methods, each possibly accessing different private members of the outer class, so we would have to try adding bridge methods (to the outer class) for each statically compiled inner node and keep track of which private members we'd already added bridge methods for. This would add some complexity to the implementation, but I think it would be ok. Does that sound like what you had in mind?

All commits but dbfa026 are ok with me. For dbfa026 I would like to be sure, that if you load a Groovy instance and use the thread local, that the JVM can still later unload it again and there is no JDK-internal data structure preventing this.

For now I have merged just the main commit that addresses the issue, minus the 2 test cases that relied on internal Thread fields.

The other commits I will break out into separate PR's if I can get more comfortable that they wont cause problems.
How does the situation with CachedMethod change if the generated closure is public?

> How does the situation with CachedMethod change if the generated closure is public?

It also means code running under securitymanager can invoke it without granting `ReflectPermission("suppressAccessChecks")` which is dangerous.

Basically, groovy should respect java's access modifiers here.

The choice was not really arbitrary. Anonymous inner classes will also not be public in Java. But well... I think there will be no real ill side effects we have to fear here. So +1 from my side... Only a minor improvement could be done and that is either to comment in code or at least in the commit message as of why we use public. Otherwise it might be changed again in the future... And of course something like a test would be nice too, but the comment is more important to me
@blackdrag I've added a comment to the code and an explanation for the code change in the commit message. Please let me know if anything else is needed to get this in.

To add to it being public, I looked for other usage of `getOrAddClosureClass` and I only found two other instances, both of which also pass `ACC_PUBLIC`:
- [org.codehaus.groovy.classgen.AsmClassGenerator#453](https://github.com/apache/groovy/blob/GROOVY_2_4_5/src/main/org/codehaus/groovy/classgen/AsmClassGenerator.java#L453)
- [org.codehaus.groovy.classgen.AsmClassGenerator#1902](https://github.com/apache/groovy/blob/GROOVY_2_4_5/src/main/org/codehaus/groovy/classgen/AsmClassGenerator.java#L1902)

Perhaps a future PR should deprecate the method and remove the second argument, but I'm happy to see the +1 here. (PS: Jenkins failed to actually start Gradle, which is why the build failed)
those other two findings are for Closures in annotations. They actually do need to be public. Anyway... +1 for the change
Rebased to merge changes that were commited as part of PR #220.

Looks like useful wrapper.  For a new feature like this it would be good to have a JIRA ticket since that might spark more discussion (and helps tie features to a release).

A couple of things come to mind in working with it.  Not proposing any changes to what's been proposed, just thinking out loud:
1. Would it make sense to also define a `bufferedIterator` method on `Iterable` so you could do something like `[1,2].bufferedIterator`?
2. Since it's an extension of the `Iterator` interface would it make sense to also define this new type `groovy.util.BufferedIterator` as an Interface with the implementation used by `DefaultGroovyMethods` coming from `org.codehaus.groovy.util`?  Don't have a compelling reason for this since I doubt there'd been too many implementation of it, just tend to prefer interfaces for new types rather than concrete classes but this could be considered more a wrapper than new type.

Good point.  I'll create a jira issue to track this.  As for `bufferedIterator`, I don't see much advantage to calling `iterable.bufferedIterator()` over `iterable.iterator().buffered()`.  I guess it's a matter of taste.  I like the idea of exporting interfaces in the official namespace with implementations in `org.codehaus`, but it might be overkill in this instance.  I can't think of a reason you'd want an alternative implementation of `BufferedIterator`.

Thanks for the feedback!

it might be worth also looking at http://docs.guava-libraries.googlecode.com/git/javadoc/com/google/common/collect/PeekingIterator.html They use peek instead of head and they support remove, but say it can be unspecified. Now, while the current implementation here does not really support a combination of remove and head, I can think of a collection class implementation that is able to do so. So it might actually be worth to go through an interface.... especially in combination with `bufferedIterator()`.

Ok, I've updated the pull request.  As suggested, I made `BufferedIterator` an interface and created implementations in `org.codehaus.groovy.util`.  A list specific version supports the `remove()` operation.  Finally,  new methods `Iterable.bufferedIterator()` and `List.bufferedIterator()` each return an appropriate implementation.

Looks good, just had a few very minor comments.  In my opinion I do like how guava allows remove if peek hadn't been previously called.  That seems more flexible by allowing it to be used as a normal iterator if needed.
Fixed the documentation errors and implemented `remove()` for `IteratorBufferedIterator` in the cases where it would be correct.
Merged - thanks!
+1 from my side

One question: I'm directly calling `self.entrySet().iterator()`, whereas the existing `Collection` method does `InvokerHelper.asIterator(self)`. Should I also use `InvokerHelper` to get the `entrySet()` as well as its `iterator()`?
Nice work. Looks good to me.
Merged, thanks!

The proposed code changes look good. However, for consistency with several other AST transforms, I think we should have an `includeSuperProperties` flag to turn on this behavior. Also, we need to update the `Builder` section of the `core-metaprogramming.adoc` file with doco/examples.
Merged: 7ced8a2cacbe0c2cf824eceac431d8a2f02de8f4 Thanks!

Based on the feedback and with releases possibly coming soon and lack of time, it's probably best to defer this.  I am closing this PR and will keep track of the JIRA ticket and work towards conversion in the future.
